Traditionally, piety has been viewed as badge of integrity within all religions, including those not of the Abrahamic tradition. This is because of the rigors required by living a pious life. Anyone that can accomplish that must be a good and decent person. Well, that's the tradition.

This is nothing but political pandering. It is an attempt to wrap oneself in the cloak of religion to appear righteous, just and trustworthy. Even when politicians are caught red handed in some kind of fraud or crime, the first the they always say is, "I'll pray on it" like they will receive divine instructions.

This is not a Christian nation. The founding fathers were deists. They believed that God created the universe, but after creation, it was hands off. The universe runs on its own. No divine intervention.

America is born of secular, enlightenment philosophy based in reason. Many of the phrases commonly used circa 1800 that invoked religion, were just that, common phrases. They didn't carry the same meaning that modern religious types assign to them.

Conservatives that use religion to justify ignorant policy are just using ignorance to justify more ignorance. It sound really good. Opposing them with reason and science puts the opposer in the position of appearing non-pious, or untrustworthy. Religion is like the poison pill of politics. Accept it and promote its false claims to appear trustworthy, or reject it, embrace reason, and appear untrustworthy.

I think that Article VI is pretty clear on this topic, no Amendment needed:

"The Senators and Representatives before mentioned, and the Members of the several State Legislatures, and all executive and judicial Officers, both of the United States and of the several States, shall be bound by Oath or Affirmation, to support this Constitution; but no religious Test shall ever be required as a Qualification to any Office or public Trust under the United States."
Yes, and thank you for your words.

Thank you for this eloquent warning.  Having lived in the Bible Belt for over 30 years, I can attest that what these people want is a theocracy.  They are no better than any other religious extremist group and have, over the course of 3.5 decades, accumulated enough power and brainwashed enough people to achieve that goal, if given a fraction of a chance.  Every day seems to bring us closer to the Republic of Gilead.

The "prayer in politics" issue is much worse than just pandering.  I believe that Mike Huckabee and others who spout Religious Right dogma are true believers in its restrictive narrow limited often bigoted derisive views.  And even worse, they are deliriously attached to those beliefs--which they perceive as the one and only truth--no less than Linus is attached to his blanket--and perhaps for similar reasons. Thus it must be made clear that the president always has and always will address the nation from behind a podium not a pulpit.

ISIS should not be given time and space to grow in other parts of the world. The U.S. should use its influence in the Middle East, Pakistan and Afghanistan and see that ISIS does not start its branch in those countries. After all, prevention is better than cure. With the death of Osama bin laden, Al Qeda has not produced any charismatic leader and as a result, it has steadily lost its cadre. ISIS has utilized this opportunity to attract finance and terrorists from Al Qaeda.
Need of the hour is a full scale war on ISIS, to root them out completely, before they spread out their deadly tentacles to other parts of the world. The U.S. should, naturally, take the lead. The question whether the U.S. should send its troops to Syria and Iraq should depend upon the progress made during the progress of war. The U.S. should limit its role, as of now, to air strikes and providing intelligence to its Allies in the Middle East, and allow them to carry out ground operations. Sooner the better.
But Bill Clinton was smart enough not to get us involved in wars like Bush II did, even though Clinton was under pressure to do so.

This new Caliphate concept is a puzzle for American thinking. How often do we hear US generals propose the same old solutions. There is a terribly need for a totally new approach to this kind of group. Now longer will the old methods, which did not work in Afghanistan and Iraq work. The total American military complex must wake up to a different day. It is time to get out of the military straight-jacket which produced the mess of Vietnam, Iraq and Afghanistan. ISIS is not going to invade America. A few jihadists returning is not an invasion. Yet all we hear from military persons is boots on the ground. Do they really think another ground war is the answer. This is a different group-and calls for different answers. Someone should be asking "what is the mandate in Iraq, Syria"  and why does American military need to be involved. American troops have died in Vietnam, Iraq and Afghanistan without any clear idea of why they were there or why they were asked to go in harms way. Certainly, the world must face ISIS and branches with a new kind of thinking-both politically and militarily. If ever there was a time for "new think" military leaders to emerge in US it is now. If that does not happen, America may be in for more tragic engagements with tragic results. Since US backing the Iraqi Shia army has shown how futile that is-and how politically damaging it is-a new think about that needs to surface.

This kind of holier-than-thou attitude made life so hard when I was dealing with a similar issue for my son. I am on the "fluffy" side, and so everyone assumed that when I was concerned about my son not eating, it was just because I had no understanding of what normal weight is. He was below the 1st percentile, but that wasn't the issue for us - it was that eating caused him pain. I would put food in front of him, that I knew he liked, he would dig in with glee and enthusiasm - and after one or two bites, would stop and be doubled over with pain. After a while, he just stopped eating. All he would eat was green beans. I can't tell you how many parents told me they "wished they had my problem", as my son got thinner and thinner, stopped growing, and grew pinched and pale and listless.

In the end, I was the one who figured out what was wrong, and found a doctor who was a specialist in the area; finally got him tested; and finally got him cured. He lost 6 years of growth because, well, "you know, goodness me, imagine that, a child who actually eats the right amount, stop the presses! Maybe you should take a hint from your kid (you fat idiot)."

He's still small - partly because he lost years of growth, more because that seems to just be who he is. But it's fine now, because he is healthy.

But while ti was going on, I got your attitude all the time. ANd it was not only smug and annoying, but wrong, When it was given to me by the doctors, it could have been life threatening.
